articles.headline: What Elon Musk Is Doing to Twitter Is What He Did at Tesla and SpaceX
articles.snippet: Firing people. Talking of bankruptcy. Telling workers to be “hard core.” Mr. Musk has repeatedly used those tactics at many of his companies.
articles.abstract: Firing people. Talking of bankruptcy. Telling workers to be “hard core.” Mr. Musk has repeatedly used those tactics at many of his companies.
articles.lead_paragraph: Elon Musk was sleeping at the office. He dismissed employees and executives at will. And he lamented his company was on the verge of bankruptcy.
articles.byline: By Ryan Mac and Jack Ewing

articles.headline: Iger’s Sudden Return to Disney Shocks a Discontented Kingdom
articles.snippet: After Bob Chapek, the departing chief executive, tried to put a sunny spin on a disastrous earnings report this month, senior Disney leaders began talking about resigning.
articles.abstract: After Bob Chapek, the departing chief executive, tried to put a sunny spin on a disastrous earnings report this month, senior Disney leaders began talking about resigning.
articles.lead_paragraph: After a transition marked by numerous setbacks, some self-inflicted, Bob Chapek seemed by early fall to have finally found his footing after two years as Disney’s chief executive.
articles.byline: By Brooks Barnes, Benjamin Mullin and James B. Stewart

articles.headline: For Ukraine, So Much Unexpected Success, and Yet So Far to Go
articles.snippet: Ukraine is on the offensive along most of the 600-mile front line, and the Russians are in a defensive crouch. But about one-fifth of Ukrainian territory is still occupied by Russia.
articles.abstract: Ukraine is on the offensive along most of the 600-mile front line, and the Russians are in a defensive crouch. But about one-fifth of Ukrainian territory is still occupied by Russia.
articles.lead_paragraph: KYIV, Ukraine — In forests, in fields and in fierce urban combat, the Ukrainian military has defied the odds, and all expectations, and forced Russia into multiple retreats over nine brutal, bloody months of war.
articles.byline: By Marc Santora and Andrew E. Kramer

articles.headline: Europe’s Wind Industry Is Stumbling When It’s Needed Most
articles.snippet: Makers of wind turbines are reporting mounting losses, and fret about losing out to rivals from China, as countries chase ambitious clean energy targets.
articles.abstract: Makers of wind turbines are reporting mounting losses, and fret about losing out to rivals from China, as countries chase ambitious clean energy targets.
articles.lead_paragraph: These should be great times to be in the wind energy business, especially in Europe. Governments here have long promoted offshore wind projects, and those efforts have accelerated since Russia started cutting natural gas shipments in its war against Ukraine.

articles.headline: China’s Grandparents Are Done Babysitting and Ready to Go Viral
articles.snippet: Rapping grannies, crooning 70-year-olds and gamers in their 80s are challenging traditional Chinese views about aging and what it means to have a long and happy life.
articles.abstract: Rapping grannies, crooning 70-year-olds and gamers in their 80s are challenging traditional Chinese views about aging and what it means to have a long and happy life.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The 65-year-old woman crouches in a field and holds up a head of cabbage. Behind her, two friends sway back and forth, cucumber and radish in their hands. “This rotten cabbage, let’s pull it out, eat it, achieve some foodie freedom,” Guo Yifen, the woman with the cabbage, raps in a low and creaky voice in the song “Spicy Hot Pot Real Rap.”
articles.byline: By Alexandra Stevenson and Zixu Wang
